docs.snippet: SINCE the outbreak of war in Europe, South America is looking toward the United States more hopefully than ever before. For the first time in his  tory its republics are no longer suspicious of Uncle Sam as a big, bad man.

headline.main: Article 6 -- No Title; SOUTH AMERICAN NEEDS

byline.original: By JOHN W. WHITE BUENOS AIRES

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--Expansion of exports to Canada, Latin America and to the Far East in October was chiefly responsible for an increase in total United States exports in that month to $332,080,000, the highest monthly figures in two years, the...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--Expansion of exports to Canada, Latin America and to the Far East in October was chiefly responsible for an increase in total United States exports in that month to $332,080,000, the highest monthly figures in two years, the Commerce Department announced today.

headline.main: OCTOBER EXPORTS AT TWO-YEAR PEAK; Total of $332,080,000 Represents Highest MonthlyFigure Since 1937LATIN AMERICA A FACTOR Expansion of Our CommerceWith Canada and Far FastAlso Reflected

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 10--Even if the League of Nations tomorrow accedes to the united Latin American demand that Russia be expelled, the League seems destined to lose four of its eight remaining South American members.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 10--Even if the League of Nations tomorrow accedes to the united Latin American demand that Russia be expelled, the League seems destined to lose four of its eight remaining South American members.

headline.main: LEAGUE LOSES FACE IN SOUTH AMERICA; Even if Russia Is Expelled 4 More States Are Expected to Quit the Organization URUGUAY TAKING ACTION Substitute for Geneva Seen in Pan-American Society of Nations, Now a Reality South Americans Disillusioned

byline.original: By JOHN W. WHITE Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: GENEVA, Dec. 12--As expected, a negative reply was received this evening to the telegram sent by the League of Nations to find out whether Russia would cease hostilities against Finland and agree to negotiate.
